ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot more concretely about neurobio. A lot of the lecture course didn't really make physical sense to me, but this lab definitely helped solidify concepts. Several of the labs are a bit graphic with dissections and human brains and whatnot, so I also learned that I am not meant to be a surgeon.
How to conduct electrophysiological measurements on species including earthworms, frogs, and grasshoppers

This course contributed immensely to my knowledge and skills as a neuroscientist. I learned how to work with various animal models (earthworms, frogs, and grasshoppers), operate a variety of equipment (oscilloscope, amplifier, electrical stimulator, microelectrodes, surgical tools, etc.), and collect data in an organized manner. I also refined my note-taking and statistical analysis skills. The pre-lab lectures complemented the material taught in the neurobiology lecture course, and I walked away from this lab with a greater understanding of and appreciation for neuroanatomy, electrophysiology, and transduction.
Neuro electrophysiology and anatomy
Learned how to dissect different animals, utilize microscopes, measure action potentials, and visualize neuronal activity. We also interacted with the human brain.
I enjoyed learning dissection techniques related to neuro anatomy as well as visualize of live neuronal response behaviors.
neurobio lab

I learned about a lot of different techniques and how to use certain equipment. The biggest learning curve was definitely the microdissection but I also found that to be the most rewarding. Learning more about how to read and interpret the signals received on the oscilloscope was also very helpful.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this course could be much better with a different instructor. Professor K is the CEO of longwinded intros and wasting everyone's time with useless information we don't need. He made us stay later almost every lab just because he wanted to lecture us on random tangentially related topics. He is also rude and would constantly shush us and whistle at us if we were talking when he wanted to start talking. And it was never like we were being rowdy or loud. We would literally just be doing the lab, talking to our partner, and he'd whistle at us like we were dogs. The lab materials also failed to work most of the time so that was another reason the labs would take almost the full 4 hours every time.
Great class!

The labs for this course complement the lecture course well, and the pre-lab lectures are helpful for understanding WHY we carry out the experiments we do. It would be helpful in future iterations of the course to update the lab manual and -- in the case of longer labs -- to shorten the number of tasks such that students can collect reliable data without rushing. It was also noted that students in the Tuesday section often did not get data as they were the first section of the week. By the time we got to the Wednesday section (my section), we had a better idea of how to move through the lab efficiently -- but at the cost of the Tuesday students. It would be helpful to go over lab protocols in more detail with the TFs beforehand and to confirm that the pacing is suitable for undergraduates. Additionally, it was quite strenuous to dissect the frog NMJ for four weeks in a row. I feel that three weeks of dissection is more than enough for us to learn the procedure and gather meaningful data. Lastly, while the three TFs in my section were outstanding, they were stretched too thin as nearly every lab bench needed assistance multiple times throughout the lab. In future years, recruitment of a fourth TF would be helpful.
Too much dissection

Strengths - no quizzes so less stress, more laid back and learnt more from the pre lab talks with professors and TAs
Weakness - organization problems, the manual did not align with most of the stuff we did
more tips on how to do well on lab notebooks and lab reports in the beginning of the semester

A more clear indication of what was expected from lab reports. It got better as the semester went along for sure but at the beginning there were times where it was difficult to know what we should make sure to include/if there was a way we could structure the labs. But the TAs were super helpful in giving us feedback which really helped with that later on during the semester.

The lessons we learned in the class were extremely prevalent to real lab work that I will most likely be continuing in the neuroscience field. I really enjoyed being able to complete the micro dissections, as difficult as they were. I did find myself getting emotional with the flies, earthworms and grasshoppers being alive and in pain throughout the lab. I understand the prevalence of the experiments but that definitely made it more difficult for me to focus on the work at hand. Some of the experiments, especially in the bullfrog lessons were a little too fast paced and too dense so they were also hard to fully learn from while we were so focused on keeping up. I did really enjoy the anatomy lab and was very interested in seeing the human brain samples and enjoyed creating my own stain.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would never recommend this to someone who doesn't have to take it. I wouldn't even recommend this to someone who hasn't taken the lecture or would be taking it concurrently with this lab. I would recommend students who need a neuro lab to take literally any other neuro lab if possible.
Absolutely, you perform some of the most notable experiments in the history of neurobiology/
YES!! Great class if you enjoy neuroscience research!

I would highly recommend this course to any student passionate about neuroscience! The procedures can be challenging, but I found it highly rewarding to phenomena that we had studied reflected in our data. What's more, no other course at Yale provides this much interaction with neural specimens across species. We worked with earthworms, frogs, and grasshoppers, and -- in our section on neuroanatomy -- human brains.
Yes, if interested into dissections and some aspect of neuroscience then take the lab!
yeah if u like neurobiology and need a lab for the major
If you are really into neurobiology or neuroscience yes. But if not then no lol.
I would recommend this course to any neuroscience major or anyone interested in going more into the neuroscience field as the lessons learned were prevalent to the actual field.
